title: Joshua Chapter 20 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 20 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 20 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 20.

questions.question: Who did the LORD speak to in Joshua chapter 20?
options: Joshua
Moses
Aaron
Caleb
questions.correctAnswer: Joshua
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:1 states, 'The LORD also spake unto Joshua, saying,' indicating that God spoke to Joshua.

questions.question: What were the children of Israel instructed to appoint according to Joshua 20:2?
options: Cities of refuge
Kings
Priests
Sacrificial altars
questions.correctAnswer: Cities of refuge
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:2 commands the children of Israel to appoint cities of refuge as instructed by Moses.

questions.question: Who could flee to the cities of refuge?
options: A slayer who kills unknowingly
A thief
A false prophet
An unclean person
questions.correctAnswer: A slayer who kills unknowingly
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:3 explains that the slayer who kills any person unawares and unwittingly may flee to the cities of refuge.

questions.question: Where must the slayer stand to declare his cause when fleeing to a city of refuge?
options: At the entering of the gate of the city
At the altar
In the marketplace
On the city wall
questions.correctAnswer: At the entering of the gate of the city
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 says the slayer shall stand at the entering of the gate of the city and declare his cause to the elders.

questions.question: True or False: The city elders could refuse to take in the slayer who fled to the city of refuge.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 states the elders shall take him into the city and give him a place to dwell.

questions.question: What would the city not do if the avenger of blood pursued the slayer?
options: Deliver the slayer to his hand
Hide the slayer
Send the slayer away
Ignore the avenger
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver the slayer to his hand
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:5 says the city shall not deliver the slayer into the hand of the avenger of blood.

questions.question: Why would the city not deliver the slayer to the avenger of blood?
options: Because he smote his neighbor unwittingly and hated him not beforetime
Because the slayer was innocent
Because the avenger was not allowed in the city
Because the slayer was a priest
questions.correctAnswer: Because he smote his neighbor unwittingly and hated him not beforetime
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:5 explains the slayer was not given up because the killing was unintentional and without prior hatred.

questions.question: How long was the slayer to remain in the city of refuge?
options: Until the death of the high priest
For seven years
Until the harvest season
Until the elders allowed him to leave
questions.correctAnswer: Until the death of the high priest
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 states the slayer shall dwell there until the death of the high priest in those days.

questions.question: Which city was appointed in Galilee in mount Naphtali?
options: Kedesh
Shechem
Hebron
Bezer
questions.correctAnswer: Kedesh
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:7 lists Kedesh in Galilee in mount Naphtali as one of the cities of refuge.

questions.question: True or False: Shechem was appointed as a city of refuge in mount Ephraim.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:7 states Shechem was appointed in mount Ephraim as a city of refuge.

questions.question: What is another name for Kirjatharba mentioned in Joshua 20:7?
options: Hebron
Ramoth
Golan
Bezer
questions.correctAnswer: Hebron
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:7 notes that Kirjatharba is also called Hebron in the mountain of Judah.

questions.question: Which city was appointed in the wilderness upon the plain from the tribe of Reuben?
options: Bezer
Ramoth
Golan
Kedesh
questions.correctAnswer: Bezer
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:8 indicates Bezer was appointed in the wilderness upon the plain out of the tribe of Reuben.

questions.question: Ramoth was appointed as a city of refuge from which tribe?
options: Gad
Manasseh
Judah
Ephraim
questions.correctAnswer: Gad
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:8 shows Ramoth in Gilead was appointed from the tribe of Gad.

questions.question: True or False: Golan in Bashan was appointed from the tribe of Manasseh.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:8 states Golan in Bashan was from the tribe of Manasseh.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: These cities were appointed for all the children of Israel, and for the ______ that sojourneth among them.
options: stranger
king
priest
soldier
questions.correctAnswer: stranger
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:9 mentions the cities were for the children of Israel and the stranger that sojourneth among them.

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 20 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 20 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Joshua 20 teach us about the importance of providing refuge and protection to those who have unintentionally caused harm?
options: By appointing cities of refuge where the slayer may flee
By punishing all slayers without distinction
By ignoring accidental killings
By allowing the avenger to immediately take revenge
questions.correctAnswer: By appointing cities of refuge where the slayer may flee
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:2-3 commands appointing cities of refuge for those who kill unintentionally to flee there for protection, demonstrating God's provision for justice and mercy.

questions.question: A fellow believer feels overwhelmed by guilt for an unintentional mistake that hurt someone else. Based on Joshua 20, what biblical truth would you share to encourage trust in God's justice?
options: God provides a place of refuge for those who act unwittingly
All mistakes lead to permanent punishment
God does not forgive unintentional acts
We must hide and avoid community
questions.correctAnswer: God provides a place of refuge for those who act unwittingly
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:3-5 assures that those who kill unintentionally can flee to cities of refuge and be protected from avengers, reflecting God's mercy and justice.

questions.question: How does Joshua 20 encourage humility and contentment in a believer's daily life?
options: By instructing the slayer to dwell in the city of refuge until judgment
By demanding immediate freedom without accountability
By promoting pride in one's own innocence
By ignoring the need for community support
questions.correctAnswer: By instructing the slayer to dwell in the city of refuge until judgment
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 teaches the slayer must remain in the city until standing before the congregation and the high priest's death, encouraging humility, patience, and trust in God's timing.

questions.question: How does the appointment of cities of refuge in Joshua 20 demonstrate the importance of church life and fellowship?
options: The elders of the city receive and provide a place for the slayer to dwell
The slayer is left to fend for themselves outside the community
Only the high priest can decide the slayer's fate without community input
The cities are only for the wealthy and powerful
questions.correctAnswer: The elders of the city receive and provide a place for the slayer to dwell
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 highlights the elders' role in receiving the slayer and providing shelter, showing the community's responsibility to care for and protect others.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 20, the avenger of blood is allowed to capture the slayer even if the killing was unintentional.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:5 clearly states the avenger must not deliver the slayer into his hand because the killing was unintentional and without hatred.

questions.question: How can Joshua 20 guide a believer in dealing with temptation to seek revenge against those who have wronged them unintentionally?
options: By trusting God's appointed justice and practicing forgiveness
By taking immediate revenge to satisfy anger
By avoiding all contact with the offender
By ignoring God's commands about justice
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God's appointed justice and practicing forgiveness
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:5-6 teaches that God provides refuge and justice through the cities of refuge, encouraging believers to leave vengeance to God and forgive.

questions.question: Which cities were appointed as cities of refuge on the west side of the Jordan River according to Joshua 20?
options: Kedesh, Shechem, Kirjatharba
Bezer, Ramoth, Golan
Jericho, Hebron, Gilead
Bethlehem, Shiloh, Nazareth
questions.correctAnswer: Kedesh, Shechem, Kirjatharba
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:7 lists Kedesh in Galilee, Shechem in Ephraim, and Kirjatharba (Hebron) in Judah as cities on the west of Jordan.

questions.question: How does Joshua 20 illustrate the biblical virtue of integrity in daily life?
options: By requiring the slayer to declare his cause honestly to the elders
By allowing liars to take refuge
By hiding the truth from the congregation
By punishing people without hearing their case
questions.correctAnswer: By requiring the slayer to declare his cause honestly to the elders
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 shows the necessity of truthfulness as the slayer must openly declare the reason for fleeing to the elders, demonstrating integrity.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear of unjust punishment for a past mistake. What biblical truth from Joshua 20 would you share about God's provision for justice?
options: God commands cities of refuge to protect the innocent who acted unwittingly
God ignores accidental mistakes
God punishes all mistakes equally
God asks the avenger to act quickly
questions.correctAnswer: God commands cities of refuge to protect the innocent who acted unwittingly
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:2-3 and 20:9 show that God provides refuge and protection for those who sin without intent, ensuring justice and mercy.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 20, the cities of refuge were appointed only for the children of Israel, excluding strangers living among them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:9 explicitly states the cities of refuge were for all Israel and for the stranger who sojourns among them.

questions.question: How does Joshua 20 teach believers about perseverance through trials and waiting on God's timing?
options: The slayer must remain in the city until judgment and the high priest's death
The slayer is immediately set free without trial
The slayer must flee forever without resolution
The slayer is left to face the avenger immediately
questions.correctAnswer: The slayer must remain in the city until judgment and the high priest's death
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 instructs the slayer to stay in the city of refuge until standing before the congregation and the death of the high priest, teaching patience and trust in God's timing.

questions.question: Which tribes were given cities of refuge on the east side of the Jordan River according to Joshua 20?
options: Reuben, Gad, Manasseh
Naphtali, Ephraim, Judah
Benjamin, Simeon, Levi
Dan, Asher, Issachar
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben, Gad, Manasseh
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:8 states that Bezer was from Reuben, Ramoth from Gad, and Golan from Manasseh were appointed east of the Jordan.

questions.question: How does Joshua 20 encourage believers in practicing forgiveness and reconciliation in family and community life?
options: By protecting the one who killed unintentionally from vengeance
By encouraging immediate retaliation
By isolating the offender permanently
By ignoring the offense completely
questions.correctAnswer: By protecting the one who killed unintentionally from vengeance
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:5 shows God’s provision to prevent vengeance on those who sinned unintentionally, promoting forgiveness and peace.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Joshua 20 instructs that the slayer must dwell in the city of refuge until he stands before the congregation for ______ and until the death of the high priest.
options: judgment
forgiveness
punishment
prayer
questions.correctAnswer: judgment
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 clearly states the slayer must stay until he stands before the congregation for judgment and the high priest's death.

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the biblical virtue of generosity and stewardship in the treatment of those seeking refuge?
options: The city elders provide a place for the slayer to dwell among them
The slayer is left to fend for himself outside the city
The slayer must pay a large sum to enter the city
The city guards prevent entry to all strangers
questions.correctAnswer: The city elders provide a place for the slayer to dwell among them
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 shows the elders welcoming and providing shelter, highlighting generosity and caring stewardship within the community.

questions.question: How does Joshua 20 emphasize obedience to God's Word in practical Christian living?
options: By commanding the appointment of cities of refuge as God instructed through Moses
By allowing people to create their own rules for justice
By encouraging people to ignore God’s commands
By leaving justice entirely to human judgment
questions.correctAnswer: By commanding the appointment of cities of refuge as God instructed through Moses
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:2 references God's command given through Moses, showing the importance of obedience to God's instructions in community life.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 20 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 20.

questions.question: What was the primary purpose of the cities of refuge as described in Joshua 20?
options: To protect those who killed unintentionally from the avenger of blood
To serve as military outposts against neighboring nations
To be centers of religious pilgrimage and worship
To house the Levites and priests exclusively
questions.correctAnswer: To protect those who killed unintentionally from the avenger of blood
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:3 states that the cities of refuge were designated so that a slayer who killed unintentionally could flee there and find refuge from the avenger of blood.

questions.question: According to Joshua 20, who would judge the person who fled to a city of refuge?
options: The congregation
The king
The priests alone
The elders of the city only
questions.correctAnswer: The congregation
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 explains that the slayer would dwell in the city until he stood before the congregation for judgment.

questions.question: Which city was NOT appointed as a city of refuge according to Joshua 20?
options: Jericho
Kedesh
Shechem
Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: Jericho
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:7-8 lists the cities appointed for refuge, and Jericho is mentioned as a landmark but not as a city of refuge.

questions.question: What condition allowed the avenger of blood not to seize the person who fled to the city of refuge?
options: If the killing was unintentional and there was no prior hatred
If the killing was done in self-defense
If the slayer paid a ransom
If the slayer was a Levite
questions.correctAnswer: If the killing was unintentional and there was no prior hatred
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:5 states that the slayer was protected if he killed unintentionally and did not hate the victim beforehand.

questions.question: How long was the slayer required to remain in the city of refuge?
options: Until the death of the high priest
For seven years
Until the next festival
For a lifetime
questions.correctAnswer: Until the death of the high priest
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 explains the slayer remained in the city until the high priest died, symbolizing a new beginning or atonement.

questions.question: Which of these tribes was assigned a city of refuge east of the Jordan River?
options: Reuben
Judah
Ephraim
Naphtali
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:8 notes that Bezer in the wilderness was from the tribe of Reuben and was one of the cities east of the Jordan.

questions.question: What is the significance of the slayer standing at the city gate and declaring his cause?
options: It was a formal legal procedure to seek protection
It was a ritual to purify the city
It was a way to challenge the elders to battle
It was a custom to pay tribute to the city
questions.correctAnswer: It was a formal legal procedure to seek protection
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 indicates the slayer must declare his cause to the elders at the gate so they could lawfully grant him refuge.

questions.question: Which city listed as a city of refuge is also known by another name, Kirjatharba?
options: Hebron
Shechem
Kedesh
Golan
questions.correctAnswer: Hebron
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:7 clarifies that Kirjatharba is another name for Hebron.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 20, the cities of refuge were also made available to strangers living among the Israelites.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:9 states that the cities of refuge were appointed for the children of Israel and for the stranger sojourning among them.

questions.question: The designation of cities of refuge in Joshua 20 foreshadows which New Testament concept?
options: Christ as a refuge and protector of sinners
The establishment of the Church as a political state
The division of Israel into two kingdoms
The building of the temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as a refuge and protector of sinners
questions.explanation: The cities of refuge typify Christ who provides sanctuary and salvation to sinners who seek refuge from judgment.

questions.question: From a Hebrew linguistic perspective, the term translated as 'avenger of blood' (גֹּאֵל דָּם, go'el dam) most closely means:
options: A kinsman-redeemer who avenges wrongful death
A priest performing sacrifices
A legal judge in Israel
A foreign mercenary
questions.correctAnswer: A kinsman-redeemer who avenges wrongful death
questions.explanation: The Hebrew term 'go'el dam' refers to a close relative who has the duty to avenge the blood of a slain family member according to Levitical law.

questions.question: Which of the following reflects a structural literary device found in Joshua 20 regarding the cities of refuge?
options: A chiastic structure that pairs cities east and west of Jordan
An acrostic poem listing the cities alphabetically
A parable-like narrative about the cities
A psalm-like hymn praising the cities
questions.correctAnswer: A chiastic structure that pairs cities east and west of Jordan
questions.explanation: Verses 7 and 8 arrange cities on both sides of the Jordan, reflecting a balanced literary structure emphasizing completeness.

questions.question: The author's intent in detailing the cities of refuge in Joshua 20 was primarily to:
options: Show God's justice balanced with mercy for unintentional manslayers
Instruct the Israelites to build new cities for defense
Demand strict capital punishment without exceptions
Outline the duties of Levites in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Show God's justice balanced with mercy for unintentional manslayers
questions.explanation: The chapter emphasizes protection for those who kill unintentionally, illustrating divine justice tempered with mercy.

questions.question: How does the requirement that the slayer remain in the city of refuge until the high priest's death connect to wider biblical themes?
options: It symbolizes purification and restoration of fellowship through priestly mediation
It implies a permanent exile without hope
It establishes a new priesthood lineage
It forbids the slayer from ever returning home
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes purification and restoration of fellowship through priestly mediation
questions.explanation: The high priest's death marks an atonement event, symbolizing the slayer's purification and reintegration into society (Joshua 20:6).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the historical context of appointing cities of refuge in Joshua 20?
options: Ancient Near Eastern customs of kinship vengeance necessitated legal sanctuary cities
They were modeled after Greek city-states' asylum laws
They reflected Egyptian temple cities' judicial authority
They were purely symbolic with no practical application
questions.correctAnswer: Ancient Near Eastern customs of kinship vengeance necessitated legal sanctuary cities
questions.explanation: The cities of refuge address the cultural practice of blood vengeance common in the ancient Near East by providing lawful sanctuary.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 20 emphasizes that the cities of refuge were only for native-born Israelites, excluding foreigners.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:9 explicitly states that the cities of refuge were for both the children of Israel and the stranger sojourning among them.

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 20 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 20 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the primary purpose of appointing cities of refuge according to Joshua 20?
options: To provide a safe haven for those who killed unintentionally
To establish military forts
To serve as marketplaces for Israel
To be centers of worship
questions.correctAnswer: To provide a safe haven for those who killed unintentionally
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:2-3 states that cities of refuge were appointed so that the slayer who kills unintentionally might flee there to be safe from the avenger of blood. This reflects God's provision for justice and mercy, consistent with Numbers 35:9-15 and Deuteronomy 19:1-13.

questions.question: Who was allowed to flee to the cities of refuge?
options: Anyone who killed a person unwittingly
Anyone who committed premeditated murder
Only priests
Only foreign enemies
questions.correctAnswer: Anyone who killed a person unwittingly
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:3 and 20:9 indicate that anyone who killed a person unintentionally could flee to these cities to escape the avenger of blood. This demonstrates the distinction between intentional and unintentional killing in God's law (Exodus 21:13-14; Numbers 35:11).

questions.question: What role did the elders of the city play when the slayer fled to the city of refuge?
options: They heard the slayer's cause and provided him a place to dwell
They judged the slayer immediately and handed him over
They sent the slayer back to his city
They sent the slayer to the high priest
questions.correctAnswer: They heard the slayer's cause and provided him a place to dwell
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 explains that the elders of the city would hear the slayer's cause and take him into the city, giving him a place to live safely. This shows God's provision for justice and protection of the innocent (Numbers 35:12-14).

questions.question: According to Joshua 20, why would the avenger of blood not be allowed to take the slayer from the city of refuge?
options: Because the killing was unintentional, and there was no prior hatred
Because the slayer was a priest
Because the city was fortified
Because the avenger was forbidden by law
questions.correctAnswer: Because the killing was unintentional, and there was no prior hatred
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:5 states that the slayer would not be delivered into the hand of the avenger because the killing was unintentional and without prior hatred. This reflects the biblical principle distinguishing manslaughter from murder (Exodus 21:13; Numbers 35:19).

questions.question: How long was the slayer to remain in the city of refuge?
options: Until the death of the high priest
For seven years
Until the avenger of blood died
Until the next feast
questions.correctAnswer: Until the death of the high priest
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 specifies that the slayer must dwell in the city of refuge until the death of the high priest, which symbolized atonement and allowed the person to return safely. This ties into the priestly role in atonement (Hebrews 7:23-28; Numbers 35:25).

questions.question: Which city was NOT appointed as a city of refuge according to Joshua 20?
options: Jericho
Kedesh
Shechem
Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: Jericho
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:7-8 lists the cities appointed as refuges, including Kedesh, Shechem, and Hebron (Kirjatharba), but Jericho is not among them. Jericho had other significant roles but was not a city of refuge (Joshua 6).

questions.question: What tribes provided cities of refuge east of the Jordan River?
options: Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh
Judah, Ephraim, and Naphtali
Levi, Simeon, and Benjamin
Dan, Asher, and Issachar
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:8 names Bezer, Ramoth, and Golan in the territories of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh east of the Jordan as cities of refuge, showing God's provision on both sides of the Jordan (Numbers 35:14).

questions.question: What does the institution of cities of refuge reveal about God's justice?
options: God's justice balances mercy and righteousness by protecting the innocent
God's justice is harsh without exceptions
God does not distinguish between intentional and unintentional sin
God's justice is arbitrary
questions.correctAnswer: God's justice balances mercy and righteousness by protecting the innocent
questions.explanation: The cities of refuge allow protection for unintentional killers (Joshua 20:3-5), demonstrating God's righteous justice that distinguishes guilt and provides mercy, consistent with Psalm 89:14 and Micah 6:8.

questions.question: How does the death of the high priest function theologically in the context of the cities of refuge?
options: It symbolizes atonement and release for the slayer
It marks the end of the city’s protection
It requires the slayer to be judged again
It triggers a military campaign
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes atonement and release for the slayer
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 states the slayer remains until the high priest's death, symbolizing atonement and cleansing, foreshadowing Christ’s ultimate atonement (Hebrews 9:11-15; Numbers 35:28).

questions.question: What significance does the inclusion of the stranger among the children of Israel have in the appointment of cities of refuge?
options: It shows God's justice extends to all living among Israel
Strangers were excluded from refuge
Only Israelites could use the cities
Strangers had to seek refuge elsewhere
questions.correctAnswer: It shows God's justice extends to all living among Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:9 explicitly includes strangers sojourning among Israel, reflecting God's impartial justice and care for all in His covenant community (Leviticus 19:33-34; Exodus 12:49).

questions.question: What does the cities of refuge system teach about human sinfulness and divine provision?
options: Human sinfulness requires mercy and judicial protection
All sin deserves immediate death without refuge
Sin is ignored in God’s law
God’s provision is only for the guilty
questions.correctAnswer: Human sinfulness requires mercy and judicial protection
questions.explanation: By providing refuge for unintentional killers (Joshua 20:3-6), God acknowledges human fallibility and simultaneously provides mercy, paralleling New Testament themes of grace (Romans 3:23-24; Ephesians 2:8-9).

questions.question: How do the cities of refuge relate to the broader theme of God's holiness and justice?
options: They uphold God's holiness by punishing intentional sin and protect the innocent
They allow all sins to go unpunished
They are unrelated to holiness
They serve only a political purpose
questions.correctAnswer: They uphold God's holiness by punishing intentional sin and protect the innocent
questions.explanation: The cities of refuge separate intentional murder from accidental killing (Joshua 20:3-5), reflecting God's holy justice that punishes sin but protects the innocent (Leviticus 19:2; Psalm 7:11).

questions.question: What does the requirement for the slayer to stand before the congregation for judgment imply about the community's role?
options: The community is responsible for administering justice publicly
Justice is private and individual
The elders alone decide without the congregation
Judgment is unnecessary
questions.correctAnswer: The community is responsible for administering justice publicly
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:6 and 20:9 indicate the slayer must stand before the congregation, showing communal responsibility in justice, consistent with Deuteronomy 17:8-13 and Acts 15:6.

questions.question: Which of the following best expresses the eschatological significance of the cities of refuge?
options: They foreshadow Christ as the ultimate refuge and atonement for sin
They represent permanent earthly sanctuaries
They were only for Old Testament times without further significance
They symbolize the destruction of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: They foreshadow Christ as the ultimate refuge and atonement for sin
questions.explanation: The cities of refuge provide a place of safety and atonement until the high priest’s death (Joshua 20:6), prefiguring Christ who is the perfect refuge and high priest offering eternal salvation (Hebrews 6:18-20; Psalm 46:1).

questions.question: What theological principle about sin is emphasized by the distinction made in Joshua 20 between unintentional and intentional killing?
options: God’s law distinguishes degrees of culpability and requires appropriate justice
All killing is treated equally under the law
Intentional sin is ignored
Unintentional sin is punished the same as intentional
questions.correctAnswer: God’s law distinguishes degrees of culpability and requires appropriate justice
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:3-5 differentiates unintentional killing from deliberate murder, showing God's justice is nuanced, echoing principles in Exodus 21:12-14 and Numbers 35:22-28.

questions.question: According to Joshua 20, who ultimately judges the slayer after fleeing to the city of refuge?
options: The congregation, including elders and judges
Only the avenger of blood
The king alone
The high priest only
questions.correctAnswer: The congregation, including elders and judges
questions.explanation: Joshua 20:4 and 20:6 speak of the slayer standing before the congregation for judgment, emphasizing the community’s role in justice, consistent with Deuteronomy 19:17-21 and 1 Corinthians 6:1-6.

questions.question: What does the concept of 'the avenger of blood' in Joshua 20 reveal about the nature of justice in ancient Israel?
options: It underscores the communal responsibility to uphold justice and prevent blood vengeance
It endorses personal revenge without restraint
It refers to a priestly office
It is a symbolic term for angels
questions.correctAnswer: It underscores the communal responsibility to uphold justice and prevent blood vengeance
questions.explanation: The avenger of blood (Joshua 20:3,5) was a relative seeking justice for a slain family member, but God's law provided cities of refuge to prevent uncontrolled vengeance, aligning with Leviticus 19:18 and Romans 12:19.
